choices.C: Loopback addresses are used to form routing adjacencies.
choices.E: Link-local addresses are used to form routing adjacencies.
choices.B: OSPFv3 was developed to support IPv6 routing.
choices.A: EIGRPv3 was developed to support IPv6 routing.
choices.D: EIGRP, OSPF, and BGP are the only routing protocols that support IPv6.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
Link-local addresses are used to form routing adjacencies.

questions.question_text: Which two statements about IPv6 and routing protocols are true? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Answer is B LCP

LCP: negotiates link specific options
- Callback
- Multilink
- Authentication (whether or not to Authenticate)
- Magic Number (Loopback detection), etc

D
The PPP Link Control Protocol (LCP) is documented in RFC 1661. LPC negotiates link and PPP parameters to dynamically configure the data link layer of a PPP connection.
Common LCP options include the PPP MRU, the authentication protocol, compression of PPP header fields, callback, and multilink options.

questions.question_text: Which PPP subprotocol negotiates authentication options?

Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

Each of these four switches has been configured with a hostname, as well as being configured to run RSTP. No other configuration changes have been made.
Which three of these show the correct RSTP port roles for the indicated switches and interfaces? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Switch C is the Root Bridge since it has the lowest MAC address,
Therefore Fa0/1 and Fa0/2 are Designated Ports
Which makes Fa0/1 of Switch A and Gi0/2 of Switch D root ports
For Switch B, shortest path is through Switch D due to STP cost, which means Gi0/1 of SwitchB is Root Port and Gi0/1 of Switch D Designated Port

So Far
Switch C: Fa0/1, Fa0/2 DP
Switch D: Gi0/2: root ; Gi0/1 DP
Switch B: Gi0/1 root
Switch A: Fa0/1 root

For the link between Switch A and B, A has the lowest MAC address
Therefore Fa0/2 is DP and Gi0/2 of Switch B is Alternate Port

Answers: ABD

Selected Answer: ABD
Switch C is the Root Bridge since it has the lowest MAC address,
Therefore Fa0/1 and Fa0/2 are Designated Ports
Which makes Fa0/1 of Switch A and Gi0/2 of Switch D root ports
For Switch B, shortest path is through Switch D due to STP cost, which means Gi0/1 of SwitchB is Root Port and Gi0/1 of Switch D Designated Port

So Far
Switch C: Fa0/1, Fa0/2 DP
Switch D: Gi0/2: root ; Gi0/1 DP
Switch B: Gi0/1 root
Switch A: Fa0/1 root

choices.A: the operation is performed in active mode
choices.D: the cisco IOS device must be on the same LAN as the TFTP server
choices.C: the operation is performed in passive mode
choices.B: the operation is performed in unencrypted format

discussion.content:
B
The TFTP protocol does not support any authentication or encryption mechanism, and as such can introduce a security risk when present.
